_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the Shelton Terminal facility:

NGL Supply Terminal Company is committed to the safety of its workers, the public, and the environment.  Its accidental release policy is an integrated approach, involving employee participation, management practices, written procedures, and training.  NGL has developed a comprehensive Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) accident prevention program considering all aspects of process operation and maintenance.  The accident prevention program includes compliance with ongoing mechanical integrity inspections, which includes the API RP 510 Pressure Vessel Inspection Program and API RP 570 Piping Inspection Program.  In addition, the facility conducts 3 year PSM compliance audits.  If an emergency were to occur, it is NGL's policy to notify the Shelton Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency. The Shelton Terminal also maintains incipient stage fire fighting equipment on site. Additionally, this facility complies with NFPA-58 requirements for LPG storage, and it is NGL's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  The facility came online in 2008. 



A description of the Shelton Terminal facility and the regulated substances handled: 

This facility is a bulk terminal storing LPG for resale to retail propane dealers.  The facility consists of four (4) 30,000 gallon storage tanks holding approximately 110,000 pounds each of liquid propane.  There is also the capacity for four (4) 33,000- gallon rail cars onsite and one (1) 14,500 gallon truck.



There are both manual and automatic emergency shutdown systems on all LPG equipment at the site.





The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:

This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule, the OSHA PSM standard, and all applicable state and local codes and regulations.  The LPG system is designed, installed, and maintained in

accordance with NFPA-58 and state law.



Five-year accident history: 

NGL Supply Terminal Company acquired the facility in December 2013.  There has not been an accident involving LPG that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or any shelter in place.  



The emergency response program:

NGL Supply Terminal Company has developed an emergency action plan specific to this facility. In the event of an emergency involving the Shelton Terminal's LPG system, it is NGL's policy to notify the Shelton Fire Department and request that they help in responding to the emergency.  NGL has trained employees in incipient stage fire fighting.  The Shelton Terminal has coordinated the facility's response plans with the fire department; members of the fire department have been provided the opportunity to visit the Shelton Terminal facility and inspect the LPG storage system.  



Planned changes to improve safety:

NGL Supply Terminal Company, LLC will continually strive for safety improvement.  Periodic process safety inspections and Process Hazard Analyses will be conducted followed with timely response.
